message_1: How many ways can 2 men and 3 women be arranged in a line such that the women are standing next to each other?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can treat the group of 3 women as a single unit. So, we have 2 men and 1 group of women to arrange in a line.

There are 3! (3 factorial) ways to arrange the 3 women within their group.

There are 3 positions (or slots) in the line for the group of women to be placed: either at the beginning, in the middle, or at the end. In each of these positions, there are 2! (2 factorial) ways to arrange the 2 men.

So, the total number of ways to arrange 2 men and 3 women in a line such that the women are standing next to each other is:

3! (ways to arrange women within their group) × 3 (positions for the group of women) × 2! (ways to arrange men) = 6 × 3 × 2 = 36 ways.
